module.p:
Demonstrative pronouns are pronouns which identify an entity based on its spatial location relative to the speaker and hearer –
seo this (one) – proximal to the speaker
sin that (one) – proximal to the hearer
siud that (one) over there – proximal to neither

section.p:
A demonstrative pronoun can be used as the subject of a verb –
Tha seo cudromach. This is important.
Cha tèid sin fodha. That (one) will not go down.

Pedagogical examples –
Tha seo math. | Tha sin blasta. | Tha siud dìreach àlainn. | Tha seo fuar. | Tha sin glè mhath.
This is good. | That is tasty. | That is just beautiful. | This is cold. | That is very good. td. 27, 195

When a demonstrative pronoun is used as the subject of the copula is, the copula itself is usually dropped –
Is seo Dòmhnall. ⇒ Seo Dòmhnall. This is Donald.

Pedagogical examples –
Seo Màiri. | Sin an tidsear. | Siud Iain. | Sin an cat. | Seo mo phiuthar. | Sin an sgian. | Sin a’ bheinn ud a-rithist.
This is Mary. | That is the teacher. | Yon is John. | That is the cat. | This is my sister. | That is the knife. | That is yon mountain again. td. 27–8, 195

Examples with dummy subject pronouns –
pedagogical examples –
Is i seo Màiri. | Is e sin Iain.
This is Mary. | That is John. td. 27
with relaxed agreement–
Is e seo Màiri. | Is e siud Anna.
This is Mary. | That/yon is Ann. td. 27
negative examples –
Chan i seo Anna. | Chan e sin Iain. | Chan e siud an tidsear.
This is not Anna. | That is not John. | That is not the teacher. td. 27
with relaxed agreement–
Chan e seo Màiri.
This is not Mary td. 27

A demonstrative pronoun can be used as the object of a verb –
Chunnaic mi sin a-rithist. I saw that (one) again.
Bheir i siud leatha. She will bring that one over there (with her).

A demonstrative pronoun can be used as the complement of a preposition –
Thàinig iad le seo. They came with this (one).

A demonstrative pronoun can be used as the specifier of a noun –
Tha mi a’ faicinn sin. I can see that (one).
Tha e ri taobh seo. It is beside this (one).

A demonstrative pronoun can serve as a modifier of the definite article, appearing after the specified noun and any attributive adjectives –
am balach beag seo this little boy
na craobhan àrda siud those tall trees (over there)

Pedagogical examples –
singular –
an dealbh seo | an taigh sin | a’ bheinn ud | a’ chaileag seo | a’ bhùth sin | am baile ud | a’ bheinn mhòr àrd sin | an dealbh bheag bhrèagha seo
this picture | that house | yon mountain | this girl | that shop | yon town | that big high mountain | this small fine picture td. 26, 195
plural –
na taighean seo | na dealbhannan sin | na caileagan ud
these houses | those pictures | yon girls td. 26

A demonstrative pronoun can modify a third-person personal pronoun, thus yielding explicitly gendered or plural demonstratives –
e seo this [masc.]
i seo this [fem.]
iad seo these
e sin that [masc.]
i sin that [fem.]
iad sin those
e siud yon [masc.]
i siud yon [fem.]
iad siud those, yon

For each demonstrative pronoun, there is a derived demonstrative adverb –
seo this ⇒ an·seo here, at this place
sin that ⇒ an·sin there, at that place
siud that over there ⇒ an·siud over there, yonder, at that place over there

Pedagogical examples –
Tha an cat an sin. | Tha an t-aran an siud.
The cat is there. | The bread is yonder. td. 28, 195

Adnominal examples –
am boireannach sin an sin
that woman there td. 28, 195
